Bad example.

Isn't there/shouldn't there be a difference between Ults blocked vs non Ults blocked? Poppy's Ult FEELS like it is coming out of the ground. This seems to go AGAINST the theme of "clarity" Riot has been striving for.

When thinking about this from an in-game thematics perspective, it makes less sense that Poppy's ult would be blocked by Wind Wall, I agree. However, taking a purely thematic approach to things would pretty quickly lead us to making exceptions to things or accepting really odd gameplay, as per the Tormented Soil example above.

Specifically to your question regarding ults vs non ults and their relationship to defensive abilities, that's not usually a distinction we make, though that isn't to say we couldn't. However, to me that begs questions like "Should Sivir's Spellshield block Annie's Tibbers or Veigar's Primordial Burst?" 

Yasuo's W tends to follow a simple rule of "if there is a hostile non-unit object flying through the wall, it is destroyed." As a player, I think some of the best elements of Wind Wall are that I can pretty predictably know how it's going to act with spells, though I do understand the thematic disconnect.

I think you've gotten caught up in this issue of thematics. If you're telling yourself Yasuo windwall is ok because you can't be constrained by thematic issues, you're missing the point.

The problem with Yasuo windwall isn't that it violates some thematic issue. Players don't care that much about thematics -- as you note above, nobody cares that Tormented Soil affects floating champions. The problem with Windwall is that it violates player expectations.

Nobody expects Winwall to behave as it does. The first time you see a Windwall delete a Nami ult, it's shocking and surprising and **unexpected**.  The only way a player would expect that sort of interaction would be if he's seen it before, or if he somehow is aware of this rule about travelling abilities.

That rule may be simple, seen from a coding or design perspective, but it's not at all obvious, and it shouldn't be used as a reason for designing an ability like that.

> and unexpected

I know this won't be the popular opinion here, but I don't think I agree with the unexpected part here. I think if I was playing Yasuo having never played against Nami before and that wave was coming at me, my instinct would be to put Wind Wall between that wave and me.
I would expect it to block the part of the wave that connected with the wall, not delete the entire wave from a tiny bit touching it.

When it comes to how things interact we believe it's best to go for a clear, consistent set of rules where possible, so that you can predict ahead of time how two abilities will behave together. In the case of Windwall, Braum E and any other missile stopping effects we might someday do, that meant we needed to develop a set of rules on what they would and wouldn't stop, with the goal of keeping those rules as clear cut as possible. What we ended up with is basically:

* Missile blocking effects will stop all projectiles unless those projectiles go so high they vanish off the top of the screen. 
* Projectiles are defined as abilities or attacks that move between locations with a travel time 
* Units are not projectiles. For things that are around the border between a unit and a projectile (Orianna's Ball, Maokai's Saplings etc) a judgement call's needed, with whether or not the thing has some agency of its own being one of the key tests used to assess whether to treat the thing as a projectile or not. 

That does mean that some things that thematically don't feel like they should be stopped by a wall of wind (Nami ult, Braum ult etc) do still get blocked. That can feel a bit weird thematically, we believe that's a worthwhile cost for the gameplay clarity it offers though. Nautilus' ult is at present an exception to the above, being unaffected by Windwall/Braum E, and that's something we'll change so that it functions like other projectiles.

Do you think there's clarity value in allowing things that go 'under the screen' to bypass projectile walls in the same manner that things that go 'over the screen' bypass them?

It makes sense when it's only Naut being weird to just fudge that into being in line, but if there's going to be a design space for underground projectiles going forward, it would probably be good to start differentiating now.

If we're talking player expectations, I for one would find it to be more jarring if underground spells were to be blocked by a wall of wind that was clearly placed on top of the ground.

To address this specific case more, in practice poppy's ult feels like a melee skillshot. My feedback and muscle memory from playing vi and using her charge fist tells me that I just smacked an enemy with the hammer directly and sent them flying. The visuals don't match up with how it feels, and this dissonance would be even worse if my melee-feeling attack was blocked by windwall.

If it were an effect that went under the screen to the extent you couldn't track where it was (in the same way that a couple of missiles go high enough you can't see them at all sometimes) then that would definitely seem like a good fit. Wouldn't want to create a new category of spells that pierces missile blocking effects purely on thematic grounds though, if we were to do that would want to do so because of the gameplay effect it had, with the visuals then being a clear way of communicating gameplay difference.

I just don't understand why everyone at Riot refuses to admit that the ability is totally broken. _
Also, annies firespells dealing damage to brand? I call thematic bullshit, fix please!
An underground missle hitting a flying champ like anivia or corli? I call thematic bullshit!_
Honestly, **if you wrap gameplay around thematics, where do you draw the line? **

But Braum's shield and Yasuo's Windwall have VERY big differences that make Braum balanced and Yasuo broken.

Braum's shield destroys the _first_ projectile that hits it, and then reduces the damage for every hit after that. It does not, i repeat** NOT**, block any on-hit effects. It only blocks from one side and redirects all damage after the first destroyed projectile to Braum.

Yasuo's Windwall destroys _nearly every projectile that hits it_ for **ENTIRE DURATION** of the ability. It negates any of the subsequent on-hit effects because it let's nothing through. It also blocks from both sides and blocks_ ground-based effects_, completely in most cases, that Braum's shield only negates the damage (the first hit) to.

These two abilities are not the same. Yasuo's is considerably more powerful than Braum's.
